text:
Using code like this:

ic = new InitialContext();
ds = (DataSource) ic.lookup(dbName);

you get:

ERROR : javax.naming.NoInitialContextException: Need to specify class name in 
environment or system property, or as an applet parameter, or in an application 
resource file:  java.naming.factory.initial

In B3, Catalina.start() was setting Context.INITIAL_CONTEXT_FACTORY 
to "org.apache.naming.java.javaURLContextFactory"; in B5 it doesn't.  Maybe 
this is supposed to happen in NamingService, but it looks not be be hooked-up 
yet.
creator: fernando_salazar@lotus.com

text:
The feature was removed, mainly because the naming context provided didn't do 
much, and we feared it would cause problem if people wanted to use their own 
naming environment.

Feel free to send feedback on this, either to the mailing list, or to me, or by 
adding comments to the bug.
Do you think we should put it back in ?
creator: remm@apache.org
fernando_salazar@lotus.com
text:
I believe it should be put back in.  One can always create an initial context 
based on an environment they set, if that's desired.  With the default context, 
it enables a simple configuration for things like DataSources where:

1) I include a <resource-ref> in my web.xml
2) I then document for someone deploying my application the needed <Context> 
and <Resource> setup in server.xml
3) The app runs without any further config.

The alternative seems to be that I create a naming context of my own and ship 
it with my app, or devise a means to configure different contexts on different 
platforms.  Is there a way to achieve the simple scenario with B5 that I'm 
missing?

creator: remm@apache.org
text: Not really. I think I'll add back the feature, then.
